name: Avoid using Html.Raw() or HtmlHelper.Raw()
description: This rule reports usage of Html.Raw() and HtmlHelper.Raw().
output:
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided:
- The number of violation occurrences
- Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
rationale:
By default the MVC framework does an HTML encoding in order to prevent XSS attacks. This should not be bypassed by using the method Html.Raw() when the string is coming from user input and is not sanitized.

The most severe XSS attacks involve disclosure of the user’s session cookie, allowing an attacker to hijack the user’s session and take over the account. Other damaging attacks include the disclosure of end user files, installation of Trojan horse programs, redirecting the user to some other page or site, or modifying presentation of content.
reference:
https://kevinchalet.com/2018/01/09/why-you-should-never-use-html-raw-in-your-razor-views/
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.aspnetcore.html.htmlstring?view=aspnetcore-7.0

CWE-80: Improper Neutralization of Script-Related HTML Tags in a Web Page (Basic XSS)
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/80.html

OWASP Cheat Sheet Series - Cross Site Scripting Prevention Cheat Sheet
https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Cross_Site_Scripting_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet.html

For C#:
HtmlHelper.Raw reference documentation for ASP.NET MVC
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.web.mvc.htmlhelper.raw?view=aspnet-mvc-5.2
remediation: Instead of using string properties and HTML.Raw() to include them in your cshtml page, use HtmlString properties that will do the same thing with correct escaping.
